docs.lead_paragraph: DISCLOSURES FROM A.I.G. With public anger rising, the American International Group disclosed some financial institutions that benefited from the federal bailouts meant to prop up the troubled insurance giant. G.M. UNDER MICROSCOPE More than two dozen officials traveled to Detroit to scour records at General Motors and assess for the United States whether the company needs more aid or a managed bankruptcy. [B1.]
docs.snippet: DISCLOSURES FROM A.I.G. With public anger rising, the American International Group disclosed some financial institutions that benefited from the federal bailouts meant to prop up the troubled insurance giant.      G.M. UNDER MICROSCOPE More than two...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President Obama's agenda. The administration's sharp rebuke of the American International Group on Sunday for handing out $165 million in executive bonuses -- Lawrence H. Summers, director of the president's National Economic Council, described it as ''outrageous'' on ''This Week'' on ABC -- marks the latest effort by the White House to distance itself from abuses that could feed potentially disruptive public anger.
docs.abstract: Obama administration seeks to prevent populist backlash against banks and Wall Street from being directed at Congress and White House and making it more difficult for Obama to provide additional bailout packages if they turn out to be necessary to stabilize banking system; Lawrence H Summers, chairman of National Economic Council, harshy criticizes American International Group for paying $165 billion in executives bonuses in effort to distance administration from abuses that could feed public anger, but saying bonuses cannot be stopped risks having administration look ineffectual; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President...

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Massachusetts enacted perhaps the boldest state health care experiment in American history, bringing near-universal coverage to the commonwealth with Paul Revere speed. To make it happen, Democratic lawmakers and Gov. Mitt Romney, a Republican, made an expedient choice, deferring until another day any serious effort to control the state's runaway health costs.

headline.main: With Health Care for Nearly All, Massachusetts Now Faces Costs

docs.abstract: Pioneering effort to offer near-universal health coverage in Massachusetts is entering new phase with intent to arrest health spending and to make health plan sustainable over next 5 to 10 years; Gov Deval Patrick and high-level state commission have set out to revamp way public and private insurers reimburse physicians and hospitals with new payment method that rewards prevention and effective control of chronic disease, instead of current system, which pays according to quantity of care provided; health policy experts say that conversion would be as audacious an achievement as universal coverage; state faces challenge of securing federal permission to impose changes on Medicaid, shared state and federal program, and more unusually on Medicare, which is financed entirely by Washington; graph; photo (L)
docs.snippet: In order to pay for runaway health costs, the state has set out to revamp the way hospitals and doctors are paid.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are signs that the president is willing to reverse his opposition to the tax to help pay for health care changes.
